paper_type_justification: Paper tests transfer learning hypothesis against field-verified ground truth. Core contribution is evidence about ML performance limitations in archaeological prospection, not a new methodology.

evidence: Abstract explicitly states: 'We set out to detect burial mounds in satellite imagery... Results were assessed using field data'
Two-run design tests prediction about training data selection (all vs visible mounds)
Research question posed as testable hypothesis: can transfer learning detect burial mounds?

evidence.claims_structure: Claims follow hypothesis-testing logic: tests whether self-reported metrics predict real-world performance, whether curated training helps
evidence.methods_application: Systematic experiment: apply CNN, generate predictions, compare to pre-existing ground truth using pre-specified criteria
evidence.analytical_workflow: Deductive workflow: design → implement → predict → validate against independent ground truth → report results

expressed_vs_revealed.mismatch_explanation: Paper frames as hypothesis test and executes as hypothesis test. No HARKing detected.

primary_classification.justification: Clear hypothesis-testing research: tests whether pre-trained CNN can detect burial mounds, validated against field-verified ground truth. Two-run comparison tests secondary hypothesis about training data selection.

transparency_assessment.transparency_notes: Comprehensive methods documentation, three public code repositories, explicit validation protocol, time-on-task reporting.
